project_head:
OUR NATION HAS AWOKEN TO A NEW GENERATION OF VOICES IN AMERICA SHAPING OUR NATIONAL CONVERSATION.

WE WANT TO INTRODUCE YOU TO SOME OF THESE NEW  VOICES.

videos.videoquote: “In America you have to look at it’s history, this is founded as a nation on our backs, and on our blood, our sweat our tears.”
videos.notesfromlori: Sound doesn't match the video exactly all the way through
videos.tags: Tell my children, Slavery, Profiling, Stereotype, Culture, Tension, Music, Rap, Rules
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Leighton will tell his children not to compromise their culture.
videos.intro: Meet Leighton, 22, he is president of Howard University's student association.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Black History, The future, Appearance, Stereotypes
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "[America] is founded as a nation on our backs..."
videos.videodescription: Leighton says when he has children he will tell them to do everything they can to be the antithesis of African-American stereotypes, but not to compromise their culture.

videos.videoquote: “Todays civil rights leader looks like you, looks like me, looks like my brother, my sister, it looks like my white friends my Indian friends, my Asian friends, it doesn’t have a stereotypical exceptional leader.”
videos.tags: Civil Rights Leader, Today, Modern Leaders
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Modern civil rights leaders are people who look at a problem and want to fix it.
videos.intro: Meet Leighton, 22, he is president of Howard University's student association.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: The future, Civil Rights leaders, Civil Rights today, Leadership
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: “Todays civil rights leader looks like you, looks like me...”
videos.videodescription: Leighton Watson says that modern civil rights leaders are people who look at a problem and want to fix it. He says that modern movements are lead by many people instead of a single male leader.

videos.videoquote: "From my experience I saw police as my dad and my dads friends, but at the same time he still had to have the same conversation with me as far as how I interact with officers.”
videos.tags: Cops, Father, Police, Young Black Man Etiquette
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: There are unwritten rules young black men have to follow.
videos.intro: Meet Leighton, 22, he is president of Howard University's student association.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Police, Appearance, Upbringing
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "I saw police as my dad and my dad's friends."
videos.videodescription: Leighton Watson says he has a unique perspective on police violence and violence against police officers because his father is an officer. He says his father taught him that there are a certain set of rules young black men must abide by in the United States.

videos.videoquote: “What I realize is that you have to put on a costume of success, you have to put on a costume of not being threatening.”
videos.notesfromlori: We need to fact check what he says about his SAT scores...
videos.tags: Costume, Young Black Man Etiquette
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Young Black men have to wear a "costume."
videos.intro: Meet Leighton, 22, he is president of Howard University's student association.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Appearance, Millenials, Upbringing
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "You have to put on a costume of not being threatening.”
videos.videodescription: Leighton Watson says to be taken seriously as a young black man you have to wear a "costume" of success.

videos.videoquote: “Our story is one that is intrinsically tied to the story of other people.”
videos.tags: Tell me a story you'll tell your children,
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Charlene will tell her children their history goes beyond the USA.
videos.intro: Charlene, 29, is the national director of the Black Youth Project 100.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Black History, The future, LGBTQ
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: “Our story is one that is intrinsically tied to the story of other people.”
videos.videodescription: Charlene Carruthers says when she has children she will teach them that being black in the United States is a story that goes beyond the nation's borders.

videos.videoquote: “As a black queer woman I have not ever experienced citizenship in a full way.”
videos.tags: LGBTQ , Woman , Queer , Citizenship
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Modern Civil Rights transcend race.
videos.intro: Charlene, 29, is the national director of the Black Youth Project 100.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Women, LGBTQ, Civil Rights today, The future
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: “I have not ever experienced citizenship in a full way.”
videos.videodescription: Charlene Carruthers says that modern civil rights activists are fighting for equality that transcends race. Carruthers says as a "black queer woman" she has not been given the freedoms that many American citizens enjoy.

videos.videoquote: “Every single day in places from Palestine to Chicago to Oakland to Montgomer Alabama, some human being is not allowed to actually experience and live in their full dignity.” Or if you need shorter “I want to live in a world where every single human can live with dignity.”
videos.tags: Dignity, Woman, LGBTQ, Government, Profit, World
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Charlene says people being denied basic "human dignity."
videos.intro: Charlene, 29, is the national director of the Black Youth Project 100.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: The future, Dreams
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: “I want to live in a world where every single human can live with dignity.”
videos.videodescription: Charlene Carruthers says that many of the problems in the United States and around the world stem from people being denied basic "human dignity."

videos.videoquote: "Now there isn’t this need or quest for a charismatic leaders, singular leader. It’s collective leadership models, collective solidarities.”
videos.tags: Leadership Vision, Civil Rights Leader, Today
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: A collective leadership is behind today's Civil Rights movement.
videos.intro: Meet Darnell, 39, he is a speaker, educator and writer.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Civil Rights today, Civil Rights leaders, Leadership
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "It’s collective leadership ... collective solidarities.”
videos.videodescription: Darnell Moore says modern-day civil rights leadership models are sustained by a collective group of people rather than one charismatic male leader.

videos.videoquote: “When folk were taking to the street, most of those folk were women, most of those were black women, some of those black women were lesbian, some of those black women were transgender women, there were men too and not all of those men were straight, or wore respectable suits or were preachers, some of them wore fitted hats and maybe did or did not go to school.”
videos.notesfromlori: Very quiet audio. Can we boost it?
videos.tags: Movement, Tell my children, Activists, LGBTQ
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Darnell will tell his children about protests in Ferguson.
videos.intro: Meet Darnell, 39, he is a speaker, educator and writer.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: LGBTQ, Civil Rights today, Activists, Women, Leadership
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: “When folk were taking to the street, most of those folk were women ..."
videos.videodescription: Darnell Moore says when he has children he wants to tell them about protests in Ferguson, Mo., and New York City that were lead by not one type of person but many, ranging from lesbians to transgender people and even men who wore fitted hats.

videos.videoquote: “It felt to me very much an assault, an attack on a place that I called home.  And that  made me very very aware of the ways people understood a space that black poor people lived.”
videos.tags: New Jersey, Childhood, Marginalization
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Darnell talks about realizing how the outside world saw his primarily Black neighborhood.
videos.intro: Meet Darnell, 39, he is a speaker, educator and writer.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: The past, Upbringing, Stereotypes
videos.videodescription: Darnell Moore says he was very young when he became aware of how the media portray poor areas where mostly African Americans live.

videos.videoquote: “It took me years to look in the mirror and say I am a black, gay male.”
videos.tags: Gay, LGBTQ, Love, Acceptance
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Darnell says it took years to accept that he was a Black, gay man.
videos.intro: Meet Darnell, 39, he is a speaker, educator and writer.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: LGBTQ, Acceptance, Appearance
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: “It took me years to look in the mirror and say I am a black, gay male.”
videos.videodescription: Darnell Moore says it took him years to fully accept that he was a black, gay male.

videos.videoquote: “I wanted to show little black girls and little black boys that they can be proud of the hair and the skin that they are in and still be accepted.”
videos.tags: Natural Hair, Broadcast, Bias, Acceptance
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Rhonda wanted to show young Black children that they can be proud of their hair and their skin.
videos.intro: Meet Rhonda, 39, she is an advocate for the natural hair movement.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Acceptance, Appearance, Bias
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: “Be proud of the hair and the skin that they are in..."
videos.videodescription: Rhonda Lee says the broadcast industry is well-known for asking African-American women to conform to a stereotypical type of beauty by straightening their hair. She says she is still shocked that she has to justify keeping her natural hair.

videos.videoquote: “I think America and black people have had an abusive relationship.”
videos.notesfromlori: Looks good, but cuts off mid-sentence at the end
videos.tags: Abusive Relatioship, Slavery, Race relations
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Race relations in the USA are like an abusive relationship.
videos.intro: Meet Rhonda, 39, she is an advocate for the natural hair movement.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: The past, Black History
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: “I think America and black people have had an abusive relationship.”
videos.videodescription: Rhonda Lee says there continues to be issues with race relations in the United States because of the long history of abuse.

videos.videoquote: “In the South you had one seamstress with tired feet one day who decided she was not really into moving to the back of the bus, and then in 2012 you have a woman who went to college several times and was on television and decided her hair was just fine.”
videos.tags: Civil Rights Leader, Modern
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: The Civil Rights message has remained the same, but the means of getting the word out has changed.
videos.intro: Meet Rhonda, 39, she is an advocate for the natural hair movement.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Civil Rights today, Civil Rights leaders, Leadership, Social media
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "The message is the same ... the method in which the message is given is faster."
videos.videodescription: Rhonda Lee says modern civil rights activists are no different than activists of the past. She says activism can be found in seemingly small decisions, like her choice to keep her natural hair.

videos.videoquote: “Today’s civil rights leaders are women, we are queer, we are low income, poor, immigrant, disabled, incarcerated, formerly incarcerated. Today’s civil rights leader looks like the rest of our country.”
videos.tags: What does a modern civil rights leader look like?, LGBTQ, Civil Rights Leader, Modern, Woman
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Average people can be Civil Rights leaders today.
videos.intro: Meet Alicia, 34, she co-created the grassroots organization Black Lives Matter.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: LGBTQ, Women, Civil Rights today, The future, Leadership
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "Today’s civil rights leader looks like the rest of our country."
videos.videodescription: Alicia Garza says modern day civil rights leaders are average people who decide enough is enough.

videos.videoquote: “I will tell my children that I fought like hell for that world, to be able to create a society where my mothers dreams could come true.”
videos.tags: Separate but equal, segregation, civil rights, LGBTQ, future
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Alicia will tell her children that she "fought like hell" for their rights.
videos.intro: Meet Alicia, 34, she co-created the grassroots organization Black Lives Matter.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: The past, The future, Upbringing, Women
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "I fought like hell for that world..."
videos.video_clip: Alicia - Story about past and present.mov
videos.videodescription: Alicia Garza says her mother grew up in the United States during, "separate but equal." She says her mother warned her that while she could be anything she wanted to be, it would be harder because she was a black woman.

videos.videoquote: “When I think about black history I think about what’s the state of our country now, how far have we come and how far do we still have to go.”
videos.tags: How far have we come?, Women, incarceration, police violence, Black History, Black future
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Instead of Black History, let's talk about Black future.
videos.intro: Meet Alicia, 34, she co-created the grassroots organization Black Lives Matter.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Women, The future, Police, Incarceration, Black History, Dreams, Civil Rights today
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "How far have we come and how far do we still have to go?"
videos.videodescription: Alicia Garza says instead of talking about black history, she likes to talk about black future, and the issues affecting black Americans today.

videos.videoquote: “It was an opportunity for us to send a love note to our communities to say that no we don’t deserve to be hunted and tracked in our neighborhoods, that we don’t deserve to be shot down in cold blood…”
videos.tags: George Zimmerman, Things need to change, Black Lives Matter, Community
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: The #BlackLivesMatter movement is as a love note to the Black community.
videos.intro: Meet Alicia, 34, she co-created the grassroots organization Black Lives Matter.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Police, Social media
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "We don’t deserve to be shot down in cold blood…”
videos.videodescription: Alicia Garza says she started #BlackLivesMatter after George Zimmerman was acquitted for killing Trayvon Martin. She says #BlackLivesMatter is a "love note" to black Americans.

videos.videoquote: “Can you recite the constitution of the United States, can you recite the constitution of the state of Georgia? And if by chance the individuals had memorized those two documents they would then maybe take a bar of soap and say tell me how many bubbles are in this bar of soap?” or “He would remind me that the right to vote is a sacred privilege that your grandfather never had and many people died so that you would have it, so it is your privilege and your right to pass on these stories to your children.”
videos.tags: Tell me a story you'll tell your children, Voting Rights Act, Past, Black History, Georgia, Poll Tests
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Voting is a scared privilge that our Black forefathers did not have.
videos.intro: Meet Rev. Moss, 44, he is the senior pastor of Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: The past, Black History, Upbringing, Voting rights
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "The right to vote is a sacred priviledge that your grandfather didn't have..."
videos.videodescription: Rev. Otis Moss III says when he was growing up his father told him that the right to vote, "was a sacred privilege your grandfather never had, and many died so you can have, so it's your privilege to pass on these stories to your children."

videos.videoquote: “I think the modern day civil rights worker is more like a collage; a man, a woman, a local, global, millennial, senior, someone who is a green activist, someone who is focused on digital democracy, someone who is of a different orientation...”
videos.tags: What does a modern civil rights leader look like?, Millenial, multi-generational, green activist, gender equality, Religion, God
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Today's Civil Rights movement is multi-generational.
videos.intro: Meet Rev. Moss, 44, he is the senior pastor of Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: The future, Civil Rights today, Millenials, Leadership
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "DuWop, bebop and hiphop will be the combination of the modern day Civil Rights leader."
videos.video_clip: Rev. Moss - Modern civil rights leader.mov
videos.videodescription: Rev. Otis Moss III says the modern-day civil rights leader will be like a collage, with activists ranging from Millennials to seniors. He says the civil rights leaders of the future will embrace the best of humanity.

videos.videoquote: “I am prophetically optimistic that we have a long way to go but it’s more than a moment in Ferguson, in New York, in Chicago in Atlanta, in Oakland, it’s a movement.”
videos.tags: What's next?, Optimistic, Millenials, Future, Progress, Movement
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: This is not a moment. Tt's a movement.
videos.intro: Meet Rev. Moss, 44, he is the senior pastor of Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: The future, Millenials, Civil Rights today, Leadership
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "I am prophetically optimisitc..."
videos.videodescription: Rev. Otis Moss III says the work is far from over in the modern civil rights movement. He says it's more than a moment in Ferguson, Mo., and New York, it's a movement.

videos.videoquote: “Anyone can be an activist and at different times in our lives, many of us will be any should be.”
videos.tags: Activism, Who is an activist?, Civil rights, Everyday activism
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: An activist is someone who stands up for change.
videos.intro: Meet Genie, 30, he is a social media activist.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Social Media, Civil Rights today, Leadership
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "Anyone can be an activist..."
videos.videodescription: Genie Lauren is known for her civil rights activism on Twitter. She says she believes activists are people who see something that needs to be fixed and stand up for something.

videos.videoquote: “All you need is a cell phone or a lap top, all you need is an internet connection and you can reach thousands of people, millions of people around the world.”
videos.tags: Activism, Twitter, Modern Civil Rights, Social activism
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: These conversations have been happening for a long time. Social media allows people a platform.
videos.intro: Meet Genie, 30, he is a social media activist.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Social Media, Civil Rights today, Leadership, Activists
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "All you need is an Internet connection..."
videos.videodescription: Genie Lauren, who has been an activist on Twitter, says the social network has acted as a spotlight for conversations that people were already having about racial issues in the United States.

videos.videoquote: “Now we are saying you are going to respect me no matter what I am wearing; because I am a human being, and I am here to, and I am an American citizen and I pay my taxes and I’m trying to live this American dream you promised me.”
videos.tags: Activism, Costume, Civil rights leaders, suits and ties, citizens, American Dream
videos.videodescriptionlorissuggestionsneedtogo: Civil Rights leaders can wear a hoodie or a tie.
videos.intro: Meet Genie, 30, he is a social media activist.
videos.tagslorisuggestions: Appearance, The past, The future, Civil Rights today, Dreams, Leadership
videos.videoquoteslorisuggestions: "I am a human being, and I am here to..."
videos.videodescription: Genie Lauren says that civil rights leaders of the past had to wear suits and ties to earn respect, but modern activists are demanding respect regardless of if they are wearing a hoodie or a tie.

intro_text: WHAT PERSPECTIVES WOULD YOU LIKE TO EXPLORE?

people.person_bio: Leighton, 22, is president of Howard University's student association. He organized a group of undergraduates from the university to march in Ferguson, Mo., following the death of Michael Brown, and he helped coordinate a photo of Howard students in the "Hands Up, Don't Shoot" stance that went viral online.
people.person_intro: Meet Leighton, 22, he is president of Howard University's student association.

people.person_bio: Alicia, 34, created the grassroots organization Black Lives Matter along with several other women following the death of Trayvon Martin in 2012. The #BlackLivesMatter movement gained increased recognition in recent months after the death of Michael Brown and the protests that followed in Ferguson, Mo.
people.person_intro: Meet Alicia, 34, she co-created the grassroots organization Black Lives Matter.

people.person_bio: Darnell, 39, is a speaker, educator and writer focused on equality issues surrounding race, gender and sexuality. He co-founded YOU Belong with NFL player Wade Davis II. YOU Belong launched a LGBTQ youth summer camp that pairs teens with professional athletes.
people.person_intro: Meet Darnell, 39, he is a speaker, educator and writer.

people.person_bio: Charlene, 29, is the national director of the Black Youth Project 100, a nationwide grassroots activist organization. BYP100 educates members about issues of racial injustice and coordinates online and on-the-ground efforts advocating for things like LGBT rights, and against racial profiling and police brutality.
people.person_intro: Charlene, 29, is the national director of the Black Youth Project 100.

people.person_bio: Rev. Moss, 44, is the senior pastor of Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago. Moss' father, Otis Moss Jr. co-pastored a church with Martin Luther King Sr., and worked with Dr. Martin Luther King Jr., in the Southern Christian Leadership Conference.
people.person_intro: Meet Rev. Moss, 44, he is the senior pastor of Trinity United Church of Christ in Chicago.

people.person_bio: Genie, 30, is a social media activist best known for mobilizing an online protest and petition that stopped juror B37's book deal following George Zimmerman's acquittal in the shooting of 17-year-old Trayvon Martin.
people.person_intro: Meet Genie, 30, he is a social media activist.

people.person_bio: Rhonda, 39, was thrust into the national spotlight when she was fired in 2012 from her job as a TV meteorologist after she responded publicly to a Facebook comment criticizing her natural hair. "I am very proud of my African-American ancestry which includes my hair," she wrote in response. She has remained an advocate for the natural hair movement.
people.person_intro: Meet Rhonda, 39, she is an advocate for the natural hair movement.
